appendix.title: The Afghanistan Mission Network (AMN) Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards

sect1.title: General
sect1.para: NATO, through its interoperability directive, has recognized that widespread interoperability is a key component in achieving effective and efficient operations. In many of the operations world-wide in which the military of the NATO nations are engaged, they participate together with a wide variety of the military of other nations and non-military organizations on the ground. The NATO Interoperability Standards and Profile (NISP) provides the necessary guidance and technical components to support project implementations and transition to NATO Network Enabled Capability (NNEC).

sect2.title: Authorised Version
sect2.para: The standards extant for the AMN are described in the NISP. This is published as ADatP-34 by the NATO C3 Board. As part of the NISP, an AMN Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards has been published among the several operational profiles permitted as part of ADatP-34. The latest authorised version can be found in Volume 4 of the NISP [ADaTP-34(G)-REV1, Volume 4 Annex D, 8 March 2013]. These are the extant and NATO agreed list of practical standards to achieve immediately usable interoperability between the national network extensions of the NATO nations, coalition partners and NATO provided capabilities.
Nations participating in the AMN have agreed to comply with the AMN joining instructions, of which these standards form an integral part.

sect2.title: Application
sect2.para: The AMN Profile will be used in the implementation of NATO Common Funded Systems. Nations participating in AMN agree to use this profile at Network Interconnection Points (NIPs) and at other Service Interoperability Points as applicable.

NNEC Services must be able to function in a network environment containing firewalls and various routing and filtering schemes; therefore, developers must use standard and well-known ports wherever possible, and document non-standard ports as part of their service interface. Service developers must assume network behaviour and performance consistent with the existing limits of these networks, taking bandwidth limitations and potentially unreliable networks into account.

sect2.title: Life-Cycle of Standards
sect2.para:
ADatP-34 defines four stages within the life-cycle of a standard: emerging, mandatory, fading and retired
The FMN Profile has been further refined and also additionally uses 4 obligation categories of Mandatory, Conditional, Recommended and Optional to assist with conformity assessments. Where relevant these have also been used in an AMN context.. In those situations where multiple stages are mentioned, the AMN Profile recommends dates by which the transition to the next stage is to be completed by all AMN members. If a TCN (or NCI Agency) decides to implement emerging standards it is her responsibility to maintain backwards compatibility to the mandatory standard.

sect2.title: Forthcoming/Agreed Changes
sect2.para: Volume 4 of the Joining, Membership and Exit Instructions (JMEI) is oriented around the AMN Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards. The AMN Profile is maintained within this document.

The extant authorised version of the AMN Profile is as published in ADaTP-34(G). This formal published version of the AMN Profile is to only be originated from this document (i.e. Vol 4 of the JMEI published as NCI Agency Technical Report TR-2013/ACO008868/04).

The NCI Agency acts as the custodian for the AMN Profile and is to be used as the conduit for changes (via her membership of the AMN AWG). This must be via the process outlined at section 2.7 of the JMEI Volume 4

Any changes already collectively agreed by the AMN TCN and NCI Agency via the AMN AWG for use on the AMN but not yet published in ADaTP-34 were indicated as changes in the document. These changes will be submitted for publication in the next authorised issue of ADatP-34 (i.e. ADaTP-34(H) and thereafter).

sect2.title: Relationship to NATO C3 Classification Taxonomy
sect2.para: The AMN has been designed and is managed as far as possible using a service approach. The AMN Services are based on the NATO C3 Classification Taxonomy AC/322-N(2012)0092-AS1.

The C3 Classification Taxonomy is used to identify particular services and associated Service Interoperability Point where two entities will interface and the standards in use by the relevant systems.
Where required, the implementation of the standard is described in an annex associated with the Service.

Where a composite suite of services (with their standards) are required to implement a suite of services that are typically grouped together to form a familiar “composite service” or a “user facing Service”, then the implementation annex is housed at the assessed “centre of gravity” of the composite service. This is done simply to keep the instructions together. This applies for those services which network engineers, system administrators, users or operators recognise as distinct (e.g. “Text based Chat”, “VoSIP” or “VTC”), and for which technical skills/specialisms/instructions already exist. For Example the VTC implementation annex is placed under “Core Enterprise Services/ Enterprise Support Services” despite the fact that the VTC “composite service” is also implemented by services in Communications Access Services, Service Management and Control etc..
The C3 Classification Taxonomy is used to structure this document, commencing with Communications and working up the Taxonomy.

sect2.title: Relationship to the Future (Federated) Mission Network
sect2.para: Subsequent NATO led missions will benefit from the modular nature of the AMN Profile, which will allow for maximum reuse of established capabilities, while accommodating unique requirements and technology improvements.

Based on the AMN Profile, a Federated Mission Network Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards has been proposed and is anticipated to be published in the next version of ADaTP-34. This will support the implementation of the Future Mission Network (FMN) Concept [MCM-0125-2012].

Given the strong linkage between AMN and FMN, the opportunity to maintain a single Federated Mission Network Profile is possible in future versions of this document, but will firstly require the establishment of the FMN Governance and FMN Framework Management Structures. To this end it is anticipated that any future development of capabilities for the AMN in the future should be done in the direction indicated by the Federated Mission Network Profile.

This AMN Profile contains footnotes from the FMN Profile that if applied would implement the AMN in the direction of the FMN. These are indicated as a footnote to the referenced standard. Please note however: The FMN notes are only included for information. They are not yet approved by the AWG for use on the AMN.

sect1.title: Communication Services
sect1.para: Definition: Communications Services interconnect systems and mechanisms for the opaque transfer of selected data between or among access points, in accordance with agreed quality parameters and without change in the form or content of the data as sent and received.
Communications Services can be further defined as:

listitem.para: Transmission Services
Transport Services
Communications Access Services

sect2.title: Transmission Services
sect2.para: Definition: Transmission Services cover the physical layer (also referred to as media layer or air-interface in wireless/satellite (SATCOM) communications) supporting Transport Services, as well as Communications Access Services. Support for the latter is relevant to personal communications systems, in which the User Appliances directly connect to the transmission element without any transport elements in between.

sect3.title: Standards
sect3.para: Although the implementation scope of AMN technically does not cover Transmission Services, there is one area that provides the foundation for the provision of federated services on the AMN. The Standards listed in the table below need to be adhered to.

entry.para: ACP 176 NATO SUPP 1 (NC) provides configuration settings necessary to ensure interoperability when different cryptographic devices (e.g. KIV-7/KG84/BID1650) are employed together.

sect3.title: Implementation
sect3.para: Although the implementation scope of AMN technically does not cover Transmission Services the TCN joining the AMN require guidance on options on how to provide communications within Theatre.
The following Annexes provide guidance on implementing these services:

listitem.para: Annex A.1: Provision of Terrestrial Communications.
Annex A.2: Use of Deployable CIS (including SATCOM).

sect2.title: Transport Services
sect2.para: Definition: Transport Services provide resource-facing services, providing metro and wide-area connectivity to the Communications Access Services that operate at the edges of the network. In that role, Transport Services interact with the Transmission Services using them as the physical layer fabric supporting the transfer of data over a variety of transmission bearers as and where needed.
Transport Services are further defined in the C3 Taxonomy, however the area that is most relevant to the AMN are:

listitem.para: Edge Transport Services

sect2.para: Definition: Edge Transport Services provide the delivery or exchange of traffic flows over different Transmission Services. The traffic flows are formatted and delivered by the Communications Access Services at the edges of the network. This "edge" in Edge Transport is the Wide Area Network (WAN) edge (i.e. the provider edge). In Protected Core Networking (PCN) terms, the edge can be considered as the entry point into the Protected Core.

sect3.title: Standards
sect3.para: The AMN is a converged IP network applying open standards and industry best practices. The AMN architecture uses interconnection based on IPv4 between the Mission Networks (also referred to as autonomous systems).

The AMN was originally conceived with IPv6 as the target for interconnecting autonomous systems (although no TCN has yet indicated that they wish to implement this on the AMN). As IPv6 is also the direction that the FMN is progressing, and as the AMN will become one the first FMN instances, IPv6 standards are now listed in the AMN Profile.

It is now advised that all new equipment, services and applications must support a dual IPv4/IPv6 stack implementation to future-proof the AMN for the long term and to enable AMN to remain in line with the development of the FMN.

The interconnection between Mission Networks is based on STANAG 5067 enhanced with a non-tactical connector and optional 1Gb/s Ethernet. STANAG 5067 provides additional implementation, security and management guidance. Due to the classification level of the AMN, dedicated transmission security (crypto) equipment is used.
The standards for Transport and corresponding Communications Equipment are given in the table below.

table.title: Edge Transport Services and Communications Equipment Standards

row.entry:
1: Edge Transport Services between autonomous systems (IP over point-to-point Ethernet links on optical fibre)
FMN: A key improvement that the FMN will bring is the ability to create connectivity over a Time-division multiplexing (TDM) Wide Area Network (WAN). For this a suite of standards additional to those for a fibre based network has been drawn from TACOMs and demonstrated. The FMN Profile [NCIA TR-2013/SPW008910/01] will include implementation notes and instructions for these.

listitem.para: Mandatory: ISO/IEC 11801: 2002-09, Information technology –Generic cabling for customer premises, Clause 9. Single-mode optical fibre OS1 wavelength 1310nm.
Mandatory: ITU-T G.652 (11/2009), Characteristics of a single-mode optical fibre and cable. (9/125μm)
Mandatory: IEC 61754-20: 2012(E), Fibre optic interconnecting devices and passive components - Fibre optic connector interfaces - Part 20: Type LC connector family. LC-duplex single-mode connector.
Mandatory: IEEE Std 802.3-2013, Standard for Ethernet- Section 5 - Clause 58 - 1000BASE-LX10, Nominal transmit wavelength 1310nm.
Mandatory: IETF STD 37: 1982 / IETF RFC 826: 1982, An Ethernet Address Resolution Protocol

Mandatory (if option taken):IETF RFC 4861: 2007, Neighbor Discovery for IP version 6 (IPv6)
FMN: will implement IETF RFC 4861.

entry.para: Use 1Gb/s Ethernet over Single-mode optical fibre (SMF).

listitem.para: Mandatory: IETF RFC 1997:1996, BGP Communities Attribute.

Emerging: IETF RFC 3392: 2002, Capabilities Advertisement with BGP-4
FMN: Will implement IETF RFC 3392..

Mandatory: Border Gateway Protocol V4 (IETF RFC 1771, March 1995)
FMN: Will implement IETF RFC 4271. FMN notes: IETF RFC 4271 obsoletes IETF RFC 1771. BGP sessions must be authenticated, through a TCP message authentication code (MAC) using a one-way hash function (MD5), as described in IETF RFC 4271..

Emerging: IETF RFC 4760: 2007, Multiprotocol Extensions for BGP-4
FMN: Will implement IETF RFC 4760..
Mandatory: IETF RFC 6793: 2012, BGP Support for Four-Octet Autonomous System (AS) Number Space.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 4360: 2006, BGP Extended Communities Attribute.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 5668: 2009, 4-Octet AS Specific BGP Extended Community.

Mandatory (if option taken): IETF RFC 2545: 1999, Use of BGP-4 Multiprotocol Extensions for IPv6 Inter-Domain Routing
FMN: Will implement IETF RFC 2545..

entry.para: BGP deployment guidance in: IETF RFC 1772: 1995, Application of the Border Gateway Protocol in the Internet.
Detailed Interface Control Document for “Connection Between CISAF network and TCN networks” [Thales ICD NIP Dec 2012]

row.entry:
IPv4 over Ethernet
FMN: Suggests as Optional: IETF RFC 4604: 2006, Using Internet Group Management Protocol Version 3 (IGMPv3) and Multicast Listener Discovery Protocol Version 2 (MLDv2) for Source-Specific Multicast.:
Mandatory: IETF RFC 3618: 2003, Multicast Source Discovery Protocol (MSDP).
Mandatory: IETF RFC 3376: 2002, Internet Group Management Protocol, Version 3 (IGMPv3).
Mandatory: IETF RFC 4601, Protocol Independent Multicast version 2 (PIMv2) Sparse Mode (SM).
Mandatory: IETF RFC 4760: 2007 “Multiprotocol Extensions for BGP (MBGP)”.
IPv6 over Ethernet:
Note: No standard solution for IPv6 multicast routing has yet been widely accepted. More research and experimentation is required in this area.

listitem.para: Mandatory: IETF RFC 4632: 2006, Classless Inter-domain Routing (CIDR): The Internet Address Assignment and Aggregation Plan.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 1112: 1989, Host Extensions for IP Multicasting.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 2908: 2000, The Internet Multicast Address Allocation Architecture
Mandatory: IETF RFC 3171: 2001, IANA Guidelines for IPv4 Multicast Address Assignments.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 2365: 1998, Administratively Scoped IP Multicast.

sect3.title: Implementation
sect3.para: The Network Interconnection Point (NIP) provides a network interconnection at the IP layer for the ISAF SECRET environment making up the AMN. It serves 3 major purposes:

listitem.para: Intra autonomous system (AS) routing (routing of traffic between nations or between nations and NATO, where each nation is a BGP Autonomous System).
QoS policy enforcement (to provide end-to-end QoS for the required services).
IPSLA compliance verification (to verify end-to-end performance compliance).

sect3.para: With respect to creating the connection at the NIP and the corresponding network engineering required the following Annexes are provided:

listitem.para: Annex B.1: Connecting to the Network Interconnection Points (NIP).

sect2.title: Communications Access Services
sect2.para: Definition: Transport Communications Access Services provide end-to-end connectivity of communications or computing devices. Communications Access Services can be interfaced directly to Transmission Services (e.g. in the case of personal communications systems) or to Transport Services, which in turn interact with Transmission Services for the actual physical transport. Communications Access Services correspond to customer-facing communications services. As such, they can also be referred to as Subscriber Services, or Customer-Edge (CE) Services.
With respect to the current implementation scope of AMN, the following Communications Access services apply:

listitem.para: Packet-Based Communications Access Services
Communications Access Information Assurance (IA) Services
Communications Access Service Management Control (SMC) Services.
Multimedia Services

sect3.title: Standards
sect3.para: To provide federated services, the standards listed in the next two Tables should be adhered to.

listitem.para: Mandatory: IETF STD 6: 1980 /IETF RFC 768: 1980, User Datagram Protocol.

Mandatory: IETF STD 7: 1981 / RFC 793: 1981, Transmission Control Protocol.
FMN: Note that IETF RFC 793 is updated by IETF RFC 3168: 2001, The addition of Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) to IP. However, despite the fact that IETF RFC 793 is updated by IETF RFC 3168, ECN cannot be used in parallel to the deployment of IP encryption and therefore IETF RFC 793 will remain in these circumstances.

entry.para:
Internet Protocol:
Mandatory: IETF RFC 791: 1981, Internet Protocol.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 792: 1981, Internet Control Message Protocol.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 919: 1994, Broadcasting Internet Datagrams.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 922: 1984, Broadcasting Internet Datagrams in the Presence of Subnets.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 950: 1985, Internet Standard Subnetting Procedure.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 1112: 1989, Host Extensions for IP Multicasting.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 1812: 1995, Requirements for IP Version 4 Routers.
Advised: IETF RFC 2644: 1999, Changing the Default for Directed Broadcasts in Routers.
FMN: will also implement IETF RFC 2644. It is advisory that AMN also follows this
IPv6 over Ethernet (Optional):
Recommended: IETF RFC 2460: 1998, Internet Protocol, Version 6 (IPv6) Specification.
Recommended: IETF RFC 3484: 2003, Default Address Selection for Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6).
Recommended: IETF RFC 3810: 2004, Multicast Listener Discovery Version 2 (MLDv2) for IPv6.
Recommended: IETF RFC 4291: 2006, IP Version 6 Addressing Architecture.
Recommended: IETF RFC 4443: 2006, Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMPv6) for the Internet Protocol Version 6 (IPv6) Specification.
Recommended: IETF RFC 4861: 2007, Neighbor Discovery for IP version 6 (IPv6).
Recommended: IETF RFC 5095: 2007, Deprecation of Type 0 Routing Headers in IPv6.

IP networking. Accommodate both IPv4 and IPv6 addressing
Note that although IPv6 has always been part of the AMN Profile it has never been taken up. There has always been the intent to provide a tunnel of v6 over v4 or via a dual stack, should a TCN require it.
Due to the fact that one of the early founding TCN networks of the AMN had already implemented NAT on the already existing network that became the extension, historically NAT has had to be presented as an option for the AMN. NAT however is not in line with the openness required on the AMN and has always been highly discouraged within the TCN network. It has since been removed as an option for all subsequent joining nations.
Max Transmission Unit (MTU) reduced to 1300 bytes, Max Segment Size (MSS) set to 1260 bytes in order to accommodate IP crypto tunneling within autonomous systems

row.entry:
3: Differentiated host-to-host datagram services
(IP Quality of Service)

listitem.para:
Mandatory: IETF RFC 2474: 1998, Definition of the Differentiated Services Field (DS Field) in the IPv4 and IPv6 Headers
FMN: Note that IETF RFC 2474 is updated by IETF RFC 3168: 2001, The addition of Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) to IP. However, despite the fact that IETF RFC 2474 is updated by IETF RFC 3168, ECN cannot be used in parallel to the deployment of IP encryption and therefore IETF RFC 2474 will remain in these circumstances..
updated by IETF RFC 3260: 2002, New Terminology and Clarifications for DiffServ.
Mandatory: IETF RFC 4594: 2006, Configuration Guidelines for DiffServ Service Classes.
Mandatory: ITU-T Y.1540 (03/2011), Internet protocol data communication service – IP packet transfer and availability performance parameters.
Mandatory: ITU-T Y.1541 (12/2011), Network performance objectives for IP-based services.
Mandatory: ITU-T Y.1542 (06/2010), Framework for achieving end-to-end IP performance objectives.
Mandatory: ITU-T M.2301 (07/2002), Performance objectives and procedures for provisioning and maintenance of IP-based networks.
Mandatory: ITU-T J.241 (04/2005), Quality of service ranking and measurement methods for digital video services delivered over broadband IP networks.

entry.para: The AMN QoS standard was constructed based on the NATO QoS Enabled Network Infrastructure (QENI).

The QoS model adopted is however not quite fully compliant with IP QoS Maturity level QoS-1 as defined in the NII IP QoS Standard [NC3A TN-1417]
FMN: will implement QoS: IP QoS for the NII, [NC3A TN-1417] (the deviation has largely to do with the DSCP markings). See Annex C.1 for details.
AMN IP QoS aggregates all IP traffic into 4x classes - (Real Time (RT); Near Real Time (NRT); Network (routing, signalling, management); Best Effort).

row.entry: 1: Provide communications security over the network above the Transport Layer

listitem.para: Mandatory: IETF RFC 5246: 2008, Transport Layer Security (TLS) Protocol Version 1.2.

sect3.title: Implementation of Packet-Based Access Services
sect3.para: Definition: Transport Packet-based Access Services involve delivery or exchange of data (or digitised voice, video) encapsulated in IP packets. In the case of the AMN, IPv4 and IPv6 (if implemented) routed access services can be considered under this Service Category.
The following Annexes provide guidance on implementing services:

listitem.para: Annex C.1: BGP and IP Multicast Routing
Annex C.2: Sample Router Configuration Template
Annex C.3: Numbering Registration
Annex C.4: Quality of Service

sect3.title: Implementation of Communications Access Information Assurance (IA) Services
sect3.para: Definition: Communications Access Information Assurance (IA) Services provide a foundation to implement and enforce IA policies at the communications access level.
The following Annexes provide guidance on implementing services:

listitem.para: Annex D.1: Firewalls
Annex D.2: Intrusion Detection Systems
Annex D.3: Intrusion Prevention Systems

sect3.title: Implementation of Communications Access Service Management Control (SMC) Services.
sect3.para: Definition: Communications Access Service Management and Control (SMC) Services provide the necessary means to implement and enforce SMC policies at the communications access level. Encompasses VTC Management Services, Demand Assigned Multiple Access (DAMA) Control Services and Call Management Services.
The following Annexes provide guidance on implementing services:

listitem.para: Annex E.1: Network Management
Annex E.2: Incident Management
Annex E.3: Performance Management
Annex E.4: Internet Protocol Service Level Agreement Monitoring
Annex E.5: Federated Authentication Authorization and Accounting.
